title: The first instrument you’ll look at is the
Time Profiler
c

. At measured intervals, Instruments will halt the execution of the program and take a stack trace on each running thread. Think of it as pressing the pause button in Xcode’s debugger.Here’s a sneak preview of the Time Profiler :-

inline_content.Text: The first instrument you’ll look at is the

. At measured intervals, Instruments will halt the execution of the program and take a stack trace on each running thread. Think of it as pressing the pause button in Xcode’s debugger.Here’s a sneak preview of the Time Profiler :-

title: This screen displays the
Call Tree
c
. The
Call Tree
c

shows the amount of time spent executing in various methods within an app. Each row is a different method that the program’s execution path has followed. The time spent in each method can be determined from the number of times the profiler is stopped in each method. For instance, if
b
samples are done at
1 millisecond intervals
b
, and a particular method is found to be at the top of the stack in 10 samples, then you can deduce that approximately
b
of the total execution time —
10 milliseconds
b
— was spent in that method. It’s a fairly crude approximation, but it works!

inline_content.Text: shows the amount of time spent executing in various methods within an app. Each row is a different method that the program’s execution path has followed. The time spent in each method can be determined from the number of times the profiler is stopped in each method. For instance, if
, and a particular method is found to be at the top of the stack in 10 samples, then you can deduce that approximately
— was spent in that method. It’s a fairly crude approximation, but it works!

title: Now, start using the app. Search for some images, and drill down into one or more of the search results. You have probably noticed that going into a search result is tediously slow, and scrolling through a list of search results is also incredibly annoying – it’s a terribly clunky app!

inline_content.Text: Now, start using the app. Search for some images, and drill down into one or more of the search results. You have probably noticed that going into a search result is tediously slow, and scrolling through a list of search results is also incredibly annoying – it’s a terribly clunky app!

title: Well, you’re in luck, for you’re about to embark on fixing it! However, you’re first going to get a quick run down on what you’re looking at in
Instruments
b
. First, make sure the view selector on the right hand side of the toolbar has both options selected, like so:

inline_content.Text: Well, you’re in luck, for you’re about to embark on fixing it! However, you’re first going to get a quick run down on what you’re looking at in
. First, make sure the view selector on the right hand side of the toolbar has both options selected, like so:

title: That will ensure that all panels are open. Now study the screenshot below and the explanation of each section beneath it:

inline_content.Text: That will ensure that all panels are open. Now study the screenshot below and the explanation of each section beneath it:

title: b
These are the
recording controls
b

. The red ‘record’ button will stop & start the app currently being profiled when it is clicked (it toggles between a record and stop icon). The pause button does exactly what you’d expect and pauses the current execution of the app.

inline_content.Text: . The red ‘record’ button will stop & start the app currently being profiled when it is clicked (it toggles between a record and stop icon). The pause button does exactly what you’d expect and pauses the current execution of the app.

title: b

This is the run timer. The timer counts how long the app being profiled has been running, and how many times it has been run. If you stop and then restart the app using the recording controls, that would start a new run and the display would then show Run 2 of 2.

inline_content.Text: This is the run timer. The timer counts how long the app being profiled has been running, and how many times it has been run. If you stop and then restart the app using the recording controls, that would start a new run and the display would then show Run 2 of 2.

title: b

This is called a track. In the case of the Time Profiler template you selected, there’s just one instrument so there’s just one track. You’ll learn more about the specifics of the graph shown here later in the tutorial.

inline_content.Text: This is called a track. In the case of the Time Profiler template you selected, there’s just one instrument so there’s just one track. You’ll learn more about the specifics of the graph shown here later in the tutorial.

title: b

This is the detail panel. It shows the main information about the particular instrument you’re using. In this case, it’s showing the methods which are “hottest” — that is, the ones that have used up the most CPU time. If you click on the bar at the top which says Call Tree (the left hand one) and select Sample List, then you are presented with a different view of the data. This view is showing every single sample. Click on a few samples, and you’ll see the captured stack trace appear in the Extended Detail inspector.

inline_content.Text: This is the detail panel. It shows the main information about the particular instrument you’re using. In this case, it’s showing the methods which are “hottest” — that is, the ones that have used up the most CPU time. If you click on the bar at the top which says Call Tree (the left hand one) and select Sample List, then you are presented with a different view of the data. This view is showing every single sample. Click on a few samples, and you’ll see the captured stack trace appear in the Extended Detail inspector.

title: b
This is the inspectors panel. There are three inspectors: Record Settings, Display Settings, and Extended Detail. You’ll be learning more about some of these options shortly.

inline_content.Text: This is the inspectors panel. There are three inspectors: Record Settings, Display Settings, and Extended Detail. You’ll be learning more about some of these options shortly.

title: Perform an image search, and drill into the results. I personally like searching for “dog”, but choose whatever you wish – you might be one of those cat people!

inline_content.Text: Perform an image search, and drill into the results. I personally like searching for “dog”, but choose whatever you wish – you might be one of those cat people!

title: Here’s what each option is doing to the data displayed in the table to the left:

inline_content.Text: Here’s what each option is doing to the data displayed in the table to the left:

title: Separate by Thread:
b
Each thread should be considered separately. This enables you to understand which threads are responsible for the greatest amount of
CPU
b
use.

inline_content.Text: Each thread should be considered separately. This enables you to understand which threads are responsible for the greatest amount of

title: Invert Call Tree:
b
With this option, the
stack trace
c
is considered from top to bottom. This is usually what you want, as you want to see the deepest methods where the
CPU
b
is spending its time.

inline_content.Text: is considered from top to bottom. This is usually what you want, as you want to see the deepest methods where the

title: Hide Missing Symbols:
b
If the
dSYM
c
file cannot be found for your app or a
system framework
c

, then instead of seeing method names (symbols) in the table, you’ll just see hex values corresponding to addresses inside the binary. If this option is selected, then only fully resolved symbols are displayed and the unresolved
hex
b
values are hidden. This helps to declutter the data presented.

inline_content.Text: file cannot be found for your app or a

, then instead of seeing method names (symbols) in the table, you’ll just see hex values corresponding to addresses inside the binary. If this option is selected, then only fully resolved symbols are displayed and the unresolved
values are hidden. This helps to declutter the data presented.

title: Hide System Libraries:
b
When this option is selected, only symbols from your own app are displayed. It’s often useful to select this option, since usually you only care about where the
CPU
b
is spending time in your own code – you can’t do much about how much
CPU
b
the
system libraries
c
are using!

inline_content.Text: When this option is selected, only symbols from your own app are displayed. It’s often useful to select this option, since usually you only care about where the
is spending time in your own code – you can’t do much about how much

title: Flatten Recursion:
b
This option treats
recursive
b
functions (ones which call themselves) as one entry in each
stack trace
c
, rather than multiple.

inline_content.Text: functions (ones which call themselves) as one entry in each

title: Top Functions:
b
Enabling this makes
Instruments
c
consider the total time spent in a function as the sum of the time directly within that function, as well as the time spent in functions called by that function.

inline_content.Text: consider the total time spent in a function as the sum of the time directly within that function, as well as the time spent in functions called by that function.

title: So if function A calls B, then A’s time is reported as the time spent in A PLUS the time spent in B. This can be really useful, as it lets you pick the largest time figure each time you descend into the call stack, zeroing in on your most time-consuming methods.

inline_content.Text: So if function A calls B, then A’s time is reported as the time spent in A PLUS the time spent in B. This can be really useful, as it lets you pick the largest time figure each time you descend into the call stack, zeroing in on your most time-consuming methods.

: If this is selected, then only

C
c
or
C++
c
functions. There are none in your program, but if you were looking at an
OpenGL
c
app, it might have some
C++
c

title: Well, that certainly doesn’t look too good. The vast majority of time is spent in the method that applies the ‘tonal’ filter to the thumbnail photos. That shouldn’t come as too much of a shock to you, as the table loading and scrolling were the clunkiest parts of the UI, and that’s when the table cells are constantly being updated.

inline_content.Text: Well, that certainly doesn’t look too good. The vast majority of time is spent in the method that applies the ‘tonal’ filter to the thumbnail photos. That shouldn’t come as too much of a shock to you, as the table loading and scrolling were the clunkiest parts of the UI, and that’s when the table cells are constantly being updated.

title: Well that’s interesting, isn’t it!
applyTonalFilter()

is a method added to
UIImage
c
in an extension, and almost
b
% of the time spent in it is spent creating the CGImage output after applying the image filter.

is called from.

title: Now click the small arrow to the left of the applyTonalFilter row at the top of the table. This will unfold the Call Tree to show the caller of applyTonalFilter. You’re interested in the first row that’s prefixed with your app’s target name (InstrumentsTutorial):

title: Now you can see what the problem is. The method to apply the tonal filter takes a long time to execute, and it’s called directly from cellForItemAtIndexPath, which will block the
main thread
c
(and therefore the entire UI) each time it’s ask for a filtered image.

inline_content.Text: Now you can see what the problem is. The method to apply the tonal filter takes a long time to execute, and it’s called directly from cellForItemAtIndexPath, which will block the
(and therefore the entire UI) each time it’s ask for a filtered image.

title: This time you’ll notice two tracks. One is called Allocations, and one is called Leaks. The Allocations track will be discussed in detail later on; the Leaks track is generally more useful in Objective-C, and won’t be covered in this tutorial. So what bug are you going to track down next? There’s something hidden in the project that you probably don’t know is there. You’ve likely heard about memory leaks. But what you may not know is that there are actually two kinds of leaks:

inline_content.Text: This time you’ll notice two tracks. One is called Allocations, and one is called Leaks. The Allocations track will be discussed in detail later on; the Leaks track is generally more useful in Objective-C, and won’t be covered in this tutorial. So what bug are you going to track down next? There’s something hidden in the project that you probably don’t know is there. You’ve likely heard about memory leaks. But what you may not know is that there are actually two kinds of leaks:

title: True memory leaks
b
are where an object is no longer referenced by anything but still allocated – that means the memory can never be re-used. Even with Swift and
ARC
c
helping manage memory, the most common kind of memory leak is a
retain cycle or strong reference cycle
c
. This is when two objects hold strong references to one another, so that each object keeps the other one from being deallocated. This means that their memory is never released!

inline_content.Text: are where an object is no longer referenced by anything but still allocated – that means the memory can never be re-used. Even with Swift and
helping manage memory, the most common kind of memory leak is a
retain cycle or strong reference cycle
. This is when two objects hold strong references to one another, so that each object keeps the other one from being deallocated. This means that their memory is never released!

title: Unbounded memory growth
b
is where memory continues to be allocated and is never given a chance to be
deallocated
b
. If this continues forever, then at some point the
system’s memory
c
will be filled and you’ll have a big memory problem on your hands. In iOS this means that the app will be killed by the system.

inline_content.Text: is where memory continues to be allocated and is never given a chance to be
. If this continues forever, then at some point the
will be filled and you’ll have a big memory problem on your hands. In iOS this means that the app will be killed by the system.

title: At this point, you should be getting suspicious. Notice how the blue graph is going up with each search that you
drill
b
into. Well, that certainly isn’t good. But wait, what about
memory warnings?
c
You know about those, right?
Memory warnings
c
are iOS’s way of telling an app that things are getting tight in the memory department, and you need to clear out some memory.

inline_content.Text: At this point, you should be getting suspicious. Notice how the blue graph is going up with each search that you
into. Well, that certainly isn’t good. But wait, what about
are iOS’s way of telling an app that things are getting tight in the memory department, and you need to clear out some memory.

title: It’s possible that this growth is not just due to your app; it could be something in the depths of
UIKit
c
that’s holding onto memory. Give the system frameworks and your app a chance to clear their
memory
b
first before pointing a finger at either one.

that’s holding onto memory. Give the system frameworks and your app a chance to clear their
first before pointing a finger at either one.
